intro: Myrrhodes africanum, commonly known as the African myrrh, is a shrub native to the savannas of sub-Saharan Africa. It belongs to the family Olacaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and small, clustered leaves. The plant produces yellowish flowers that bloom in spring, followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. Its aromatic resin has been historically used in traditional medicine and incense. The plant is adapted to dry climates and plays a role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various insects and birds.
